Software Engineering Project - Course Guide

Project: Build an AI‑Driven Terminal Interface with Plugin Architecture

Project Description

In this project, you will work as a team to design and implement a modern terminal interface focused on developer productivity. Unlike a single CLI tool, you will build a full terminal experience that supports both classical shell commands and natural language prompts. The terminal should understand basic shell commands enhanced with an AI assistant (suggestions, explanations, safe/dry‑run previews) and render interactive block‑based input/output. It can orchestrate multiple AI agents with different roles (explain, execute, debug, etc.) and is extensible via a plugin architecture (at least one AI‑powered plugin).

Inspiration: Warp (https://www.warp.dev/)
Warp is a modern, Rust‑based terminal that showcases:

  • A block‑based interaction model (each command and output is a discrete, shareable block).
  • Smart input UX (command palette, rich completions, inline flag docs, templates/workflows).
  • Collaboration features (shareable blocks/sessions, searchable command history).
  • AI assistance (explain commands, generate command lines from intent, suggest safer alternatives).

Use Warp’s ideas to guide UX and interaction patterns. Do not clone it 1:1—select and justify which ideas you adopt based on your goals and scope.

This project emphasizes both technical depth (architecture, plugins, multi‑agent orchestration, safety) and professional practices (teamwork, iterative workflow, documentation, and open‑source release).

Goal

Deliver an agentic CLI environment that enables:

  • Classic shell usage and natural language input side by side.
  • AI‑enhanced shell commands (suggest flags, explain/dry‑run, warn/confirm risky commands).
  • A modular plugin system (AI and non‑AI).
  • A visual, block‑based UI for input/output.
  • Practical features that help developers (initialize projects, analyze code, generate tests, refactor).

Context

Command‑line tools are central to software engineering. In parallel, AI assistants are reshaping developer workflows. This project combines both by creating a smart, visual, and extensible terminal that leverages AI to improve productivity and team collaboration. Your design should emphasize extensibility, operability, and developer experience.

Desired Outcome

A working terminal application that:

  • Provides a clear command structure with subcommands (e.g., init, run, explain).
  • Supports natural language mode that maps prompts to executable actions.
  • Implements a plugin architecture (discover, load, configure; at least one AI plugin).
  • Renders interactive blocks for inputs/outputs (copy, annotate, expand details).
  • Orchestrates multiple AI agents with different roles.
  • Maintains context memory and supports shared workflows.
  • Includes logging, error handling, tests, and documentation.
  • Runs locally with a one‑command setup.

Functional Requirements

Must‑Haves

  • CLI core and subcommands: e.g., init, run, info, explain.
  • Basic shell commands with AI assistance:
    • Parse and execute common shell commands (ls, cd, cp, mv, rm, git, …).
    • Offer AI suggestions, auto‑corrections, and flag hints.
    • Provide explanations and safe/dry‑run previews before risky actions (e.g., rm -rf, destructive Git ops).
    • Require confirmation for dangerous operations.
  • Natural language mode: user types free text; an AI plugin translates intent into actions/commands.
  • Plugin architecture:
    • Discover, load/unload third‑party plugins (AI and non‑AI).
    • Provide clear extension points and a versioned plugin API.
  • Block‑based UI:
    • Render input/output as interactive blocks (copy, annotate, expand/collapse).
    • Show per‑block status, logs, and errors.
  • Multi‑agent support:
    • Run multiple AI agents (planner, executor, explainer) and route tasks between them.

Could‑Haves (Optional)

  • Plugin examples: refactor, docgen, lint, format, testgen.
  • Team workflows: shared context/workflows across sessions.
  • Integrations: Git, issue trackers, CI.
  • Advanced UX: themes/keybindings, command history visualization.
  • Dashboard: panel for active agents and block history.

Non‑Functional Requirements

  • Shell compatibility: works with Bash, Zsh, Fish, or PowerShell.
  • Reliability & UX: robust error handling; clear prompts; readable colors.
  • Testability: ≥ 70% coverage on core modules (CLI, plugins, agent routing).
  • Modularity: separate CLI, core, and plugins; avoid tight coupling.
  • Observability: per‑block logs; optional verbose tracing.
  • Documentation:
    • README with Quick Start, Usage, Configuration, Troubleshooting.
    • API docs for the plugin interface.
    • Example configurations and workflows.
  • Reproducibility: one‑command local setup; deterministic bootstrap.
  • Security/Safety: guardrails for destructive commands; permission prompts; redact secrets in logs.

Research & Decision Making

You are expected to:

  • Define your vision and philosophy for a modern terminal UX.
  • Compare plugin architectures for CLIs and justify choices (loading, sandboxing, versioning).
  • Explore AI interaction patterns for developer tooling (prompting, grounding, safety).
  • Review multi‑agent orchestration strategies and when they help.
  • Consider shell integration and cross‑platform concerns.
  • Evaluate Warp patterns (blocks, palette, AI help, workflows) and document what you adopt and why.
  • Propose an approach for context memory and collaboration.
  • Record major choices as ADRs (Architecture Decision Records) and include short spikes/experiments.

Project Requirements

  • Team size: 3 students.
  • Runtime: your choice; Rust preferred but not required. JS/TS, Go, etc., are acceptable—justify your pick.
  • Repository: public GitHub; use issues/board and PR reviews.
  • Setup: one‑command run (e.g., cargo run, npm run dev, or make run).
  • Environment: include .env.example; no secrets in the repo.
  • CI/CD: lint, test, and build on PRs; main stays green.
  • Deliverables:
    • Source code + documentation on GitHub.
    • Demo usage and example plugins.
    • Research notes and ADRs.
    • Final presentation and reflection.

Assessment Criteria

  1. Research & Analysis – clarity of goals, comparisons, and evidence.
  2. Functional Working – CLI, natural language mode, plugins, and multi‑agent flow work as specified.
  3. Technical Quality – architecture, modularity, tests, and observability.
  4. Documentation & DX – easy to install, clear usage, plugin API docs, examples.
  5. Teamwork & Process – iterative development, Git workflow, code reviews.
  6. Presentation & Reflection – ability to explain and defend choices; lessons learned.

Definition of Done

The project is done when:

  • Research completed and documented:
    • Vision, comparisons, and key trade‑offs are written up.
    • Experiments/spikes inform decisions; ADRs are present and linked.
  • Functionality:
    • CLI supports both classic commands and natural language.
    • At least one AI plugin is implemented and usable.
    • Plugin architecture is demonstrably extensible (load/unload, versioning).
    • Block‑based UI with per‑block logs and errors is implemented.
  • Quality:
    • Tests pass with ≥ 70% coverage on core modules in CI.
    • Codebase is modular, readable, and observable.
  • Delivery:
    • Public GitHub repository with complete README and one‑command run.
    • Demo showcases core features.
    • Final presentation and reflection delivered.

Project Tags

#cli, #developer-tools, #ai, #plugin-architecture, #typescript (or #rust), #shell, #agentic-dev, #developer-experience
